study_duration: 10 days per cycle for two consecutive menstrual cycles.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the mechanism by which star anise oil (SAO) enhances antioxidant status and mitigates oxidative stress during subclinical E. coli infection in birds.
results_summary: SAO supplementation improved antioxidant enzyme activity, reduced oxidative stress markers, and upregulated key antioxidant genes (e.g., Nrf2) in birds challenged with E. coli, with optimal effects at 400 mg/kg. The efficacy was dose-dependent.
population_specificity: 512 male White Leghorn birds (30 weeks old, ~2.14 kg body weight)
study_duration: 1 week adaptation + 3 weeks data collection (4 weeks total)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether anise oil could ameliorate symptoms of chronic mild stress (CMS) in rats, focusing on behavioral and biochemical markers.
results_summary: Anise oil improved sucrose consumption, locomotor activity, and antioxidant enzyme levels while reducing oxidative stress markers in CMS-exposed rats, bringing these parameters closer to control levels. Histopathological findings supported these results.
population_specificity: Male albino rats subjected to chronic mild stress (CMS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether aniracetam could counteract neurotoxicity induced by excitatory amino acids and potentiate neuroprotective responses via metabotropic glutamate receptors (mGluRs).
results_summary: Aniracetam concentration-dependently counteracted glutamate-, kainate-, and AMPA-induced cell death, enhanced neuroprotection by mGluR agonists, and potentiated mGluR-coupled phospholipase C stimulation.
population_specificity: Primary cultures of rat cerebellar granule cells

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and isolate a bioactive compound from star anise that inhibits gastric lipase for potential obesity treatment.
results_summary: The study identified myricitrin-5-methyl ether (M5ME) as a gastric lipase inhibitor through bioactivity-guided fractionation and molecular docking, suggesting its potential for obesity treatment.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of anise oil on alleviating mild to moderate depression symptoms in patients with irritable bowel syndrome.
results_summary: Anise oil demonstrated significant superiority over both the active control (Colpermin) and placebo groups in reducing depression symptoms at week 4 and follow-up (week 6), suggesting it could be a promising treatment option.
population_specificity: 120 participants with mild to moderate depression and irritable bowel syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of dietary supplementation of star anise oil (SAO) on the performance and antioxidant status of laying hens.
results_summary: SAO supplementation improved antioxidant status in serum, liver, and yolk, with dose-dependent increases in superoxide dismutase and glutathione peroxidase activities and reductions in malondialdehyde levels. It also showed a tendency to enhance egg mass, average egg weight, and feed intake in the early phase of the experiment.
population_specificity: 864 Hy-Line brown laying hens at 26 weeks of age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the protective effect of anise oil and its component anethole against favism-induced disorders in rats.
results_summary: Anise oil and anethole pretreatment prevented favism-induced changes in blood parameters, DNA damage, and liver histopathology, suggesting protective effects against favism disorders.
population_specificity: Male albino rats (48 subjects divided into six groups).
effective_dosage: 300 mg/kg anise oil and 100 mg/kg anethole, administered orally once daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of chitosan film containing anise essential oil (AEO) on the quality and shelf life of chicken burgers during chilled storage.
results_summary: Adding AEO improved film properties, delayed lipid oxidation, and significantly reduced microbial spoilage in chicken burgers. AEO at 1.5% and 2% showed the best results in preserving biochemical and bacteriological attributes, with 1.5% being optimal considering sensory and economic factors.
population_specificity: Chicken burgers stored at 4 ± 1°C.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy and safety of enteric-coated anise oil capsules (AnisEncap) for treating clinical symptoms of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).
results_summary: AnisEncap significantly improved IBS symptoms compared to placebo and Colpermin®, with 75% of treated patients becoming symptom-free. The treatment showed superior efficacy in symptom relief and quality of life improvement, with a number needed to treat (NNT) of 4.
population_specificity: 120 patients with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of star anise (Illicium verum) extracts as eco-friendly botanical pesticides, specifically assessing their repellency and contact toxicity against Sitophilus zeamais adults.
results_summary: The study identified 44 compounds in the extracts, with trans-anethole being the most abundant. The ethyl acetate (EA) extract showed the highest repellency (76.9%) and the lowest median lethal dose (21.2 µg/cm²), demonstrating strong insecticidal effects.
population_specificity: Sitophilus zeamais (maize weevil) adults
effective_dosage: 125.79 µg/cm² for repellency; 21.2 µg/cm² (EA extract) for contact toxicity

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the safety of star anise tea in infants, particularly focusing on neurological and gastrointestinal symptoms caused by contamination with toxic Japanese star anise.
results_summary: The study found that ingestion of star anise tea contaminated with Japanese star anise led to severe neurological and gastrointestinal symptoms in an infant, including cyanosis, tetany, and irritability. Chemical analysis confirmed the presence of the neurotoxin anisatin in both the infant's urine and the tea sample, exceeding safe tolerance levels.
population_specificity: 2-month-old infant
effective_dosage: 200 mL of an infusion with 4-5 fruits of star anise, given 3 times

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of a coconut and anise spray versus permethrin lotion for treating head louse infestations.
results_summary: The coconut and anise spray was significantly more effective (82.0% cure rate) than permethrin (42.0% cure rate), with a notable difference in efficacy. Some participants reported irritant reactions due to alcohol contact with excoriated skin.
population_specificity: 100 participants with active head louse infestation.
effective_dosage: Two applications of the spray 9 days apart (specific dosage not detailed).
study_duration: Intervention spanned 9 days with two applications.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of anise oil on ruminal microbial fermentation and its potential as a modifier of rumen fermentation in beef production systems.
results_summary: The anise oil treatment decreased the acetate to propionate ratio, branched-chain VFA and ammonia N concentrations, and protozoal counts, suggesting it may be useful for modifying rumen fermentation.
population_specificity: Holstein heifers (360-450 kg BW)
study_duration: 15 days adaptation + 6 days sampling (21 days total)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the antiviral activity of anise oil against both aciclovir-sensitive and aciclovir-resistant herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) strains.
results_summary: Anise oil exhibited high antiviral activity, reducing plaque formation by 96.6-99.9% when HSV-1 was preincubated with the oil before attachment to host cells. The effect was achieved by interrupting viral adsorption, differing from aciclovir's mechanism.
population_specificity: In-vitro study using HSV-1 strains (aciclovir-sensitive KOS and aciclovir-resistant clinical isolates).
effective_dosage: Maximum noncytotoxic concentrations (specific amounts not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-carcinogenic potential of Star anise (Illicium verum) in rats with NDEA-initiated and PB-promoted hepato-carcinogenesis.
results_summary: Star anise treatment reduced tumor burden, oxidative stress, and increased phase II enzyme levels, showing significant anti-carcinogenic effects, particularly when administered during the promotion stage or continuously for 20 weeks.
population_specificity: Rats with induced hepato-carcinogenesis.
effective_dosage: Not specified (single dose of NDEA at 200mg/kg body weight and PB at 0.05% in drinking water).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the safety of star anise tea in infants, particularly regarding potential contamination with toxic Japanese star anise.
results_summary: The study found adverse neurologic reactions in infants given star anise tea and evidence of contamination of Chinese star anise with toxic Japanese star anise, prompting a call for stricter regulation.
population_specificity: Infants

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the safety of star anise herbal tea in infants, particularly focusing on cases of poisoning due to contamination or adulteration.
results_summary: The study reported neurological symptoms (tremors, hypertonia, vomiting) in infants given star anise tea, with contamination by toxic Japanese star anise confirmed in one case. The findings highlight safety risks associated with improper use or adulteration of star anise.
population_specificity: Infants under 6 months of age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the toxicity of star anise in infants and highlight the risks associated with its use for treating colic.
results_summary: The study reported severe neurological and gastrointestinal symptoms, including convulsive status, in a 1-month-old infant after ingesting star anise. The symptoms were attributed to neurotoxins like veranisatins, prompting discussion on regulating such natural products.
population_specificity: 1-month-old infant with suspected colic.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate somatic embryogenesis in anise suspension cultures, focusing on synchronization, differentiation stages, and glyoxysome enzyme activities.
results_summary: The study found that somatic embryogenesis in anise could be synchronized by selecting cell aggregates of specific diameters, with distinct morphological stages (globular, heart-shaped, torpedo-shaped) appearing at different time points. Glyoxysome enzyme activities were induced in early-stage embryoids but not in later stages, suggesting a loss of cellular competence for glyoxysome induction during differentiation.
population_specificity: Anise (Pimpinella anisum L.) suspension cultures and hypocotyl explants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how differentiation of anise tissue cultures affects total phenolic and anethole contents, and the role of proline in differentiation and phenolic synthesis.
results_summary: Root cultures had the highest total phenolics and EPB (an anethole precursor) content, correlating with higher proline levels. Embryo and shoot cultures showed reduced phenolic and EPB levels. Antioxidant activity increased by day 60 but did not differ significantly between tissue types, suggesting nonphenolic metabolites may also contribute to antioxidant protection.
population_specificity: In vitro anise tissue cultures (A-8 clonal line and its genetically transformed derivative JB-10).
study_duration: Measurements taken at day 30 and day 60.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of an energy-reduced anti-inflammatory diet on liver status in younger adults with obesity after a 6-month follow-up.
results_summary: The anti-inflammatory diet resulted in significant weight loss, reduced visceral adiposity, improved metabolic and inflammatory biomarkers, and enhanced liver parameters.
population_specificity: Younger adults (mean age 43 years) with obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an anti-inflammatory diet could effectively prevent or treat viral respiratory diseases by examining its impact on inflammation, immune response, and infection symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that an anti-inflammatory diet, including foods like turmeric, ginger, garlic, and nutrients like vitamins C and D, zinc, and omega-3, may help reduce infection symptoms and duration due to their anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, antiviral, and immune-enhancing properties.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population with respiratory viral infections).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize available data to evaluate the effectiveness of the Anti-Inflammatory Diet (AID) in managing inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).
results_summary: The study found that altering gastrointestinal microbiota through dietary therapy, including AID, can reduce IBD symptoms and is a promising therapeutic strategy. However, scientific evidence supporting AID for maintaining remission and preventing relapse is limited.
population_specificity: Patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of an anti-inflammatory diet on inflammation in patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
results_summary: The study found no significant effects on CRP or ESR in the overall group, but in highly compliant participants, the anti-inflammatory diet reduced ESR and lowered serum concentrations of certain inflammatory markers (CXCL1, CXCL5, CXCL6, and TNFSF14) compared to the control diet.
population_specificity: 50 participants (78% female, median BMI 27, median age 63 y) with stable RA medication.
effective_dosage: Not specified (dietary intervention focused on high intake of fatty fish, whole grains, fruits, nuts, and berries).
study_duration: 10 weeks per diet phase with a 4-month washout.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a low-inflammatory diet based on Mediterranean principles could reduce markers of local and systemic inflammation in patients with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP).
results_summary: The study found significant changes in serum calprotectin, insulin, and insulin-like growth factor-1 levels, as well as a borderline significant change in the neutrophil-lymphocyte ratio, with effects noticeable after 3 months. A significant increase in 15-hydroxyprostaglandin dehydrogenase expression was also observed by the end of the study.
population_specificity: 28 patients with FAP over 18 years of age who underwent rectum-sparing prophylactic colectomy.
study_duration: 6 months (3-month active dietary intervention, followed by 3-month follow-up)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of an energy-reduced anti-inflammatory diet on body composition, cardiometabolic status, and inflammatory markers in participants with obesity over 24 weeks.
results_summary: The anti-inflammatory diet significantly reduced body weight and visceral adipose tissue while improving cardiometabolic and inflammatory statuses, demonstrating effectiveness in obesity management.
population_specificity: 81 participants (average age 43 years, 74 women) with obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of an anti-inflammatory diet, alone and in combination with cannabinoids, for managing neuropathic pain after spinal cord injury.
results_summary: The study will assess changes in neuropathic pain, inflammation, mood, sleep, spasticity, cost-effectiveness, and function, but specific results are not yet provided in the abstract.
population_specificity: Individuals with spinal cord injury (144 participants).
study_duration: 6 weeks for individual treatments, followed by an additional 6 weeks for combined evaluation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to design an anti-inflammatory diet (ITIS diet) tailored for rheumatoid arthritis (RA) patients and assess its feasibility and potential anti-inflammatory effects.
results_summary: The study designed an anti-inflammatory diet incorporating patient feedback, resulting in high adherence. The diet is being tested in an ongoing pilot study to evaluate its effects on pain and joint swelling in RA patients.
population_specificity: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether an anti-inflammatory diet reduces disease activity in patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in disease activity between the intervention and control diets in the main analysis, but unadjusted analyses showed a significant decrease in disease activity during the intervention period compared to the control period. No significant differences were observed in the individual components of disease activity.
population_specificity: 50 patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
effective_dosage: Food equivalent to ∼50% of energy requirements was delivered weekly.
study_duration: 10 weeks per diet period, with a 4-month washout between periods.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess changes in nutrient intake and inflammatory mediators after a 3-month anti-inflammatory diet in individuals with spinal cord injury (SCI).
results_summary: The anti-inflammatory diet significantly reduced fat intake and proinflammatory nutrients (trans fatty acids, caffeine, sodium) while increasing protein and anti-inflammatory nutrients (vitamins A, C, E, omega-3 fatty acids). It also significantly lowered proinflammatory mediators (interferon-y, interleukin-1β, interleukin-6).
population_specificity: Twenty individuals with various levels and severities of spinal cord injury (SCI) in the Niagara region.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether there is a link between the inflammatory potential of a diet and the risk of depression or depressive symptoms.
results_summary: The study found a significant association between a pro-inflammatory diet and increased risk of depression diagnosis or symptoms, suggesting that an anti-inflammatory diet may reduce depression risk. The meta-analysis included 11 studies with 101,950 participants, showing consistent results (OR: 1.40, 95% CI: 1.21-1.62, P < 0.001).
population_specificity: 101,950 participants aged 16-72 years old.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an anti-inflammatory diet (AID) could prevent or reverse the negative effects of a poor-quality diet (Standard American Diet) on recovery from inflammatory injury.
results_summary: Animals on the Standard American Diet (SAD) showed prolonged recovery from inflammatory injury compared to those on the AID or regular diet (REG). Switching from SAD to AID or REG improved recovery times, with AID-fed animals recovering as quickly as REG-fed animals.
population_specificity: Male and female mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test whether an anti-inflammatory diet intervention could decrease disease activity and improve quality of life in patients with stable established rheumatoid arthritis (RA) compared to a regular diet.
results_summary: The study is ongoing (ADIRA trial), but the abstract does not report specific results yet. It outlines the methodology for evaluating the diet's impact on disease severity, cardiovascular risk markers, and quality of life, with metabolomics used to predict responders.
population_specificity: 50 RA patients with moderate disease activity.
study_duration: 2 × 10 weeks with a 3-month wash-out between diets.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize nutrition interventions for weight management in obese children by analyzing the relationships between leptin, ghrelin, adiponectin, and BMI.
results_summary: Successful interventions included structured exercise and hypocaloric diets, with leptin levels decreasing as BMI decreased. Evidence on ghrelin and adiponectin's relationship with BMI was inconclusive, and common anti-inflammatory diets were underrepresented.
population_specificity: 2,153 obese children from international studies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association between an anti-inflammatory diet and 10-year cardiovascular disease incidence, and whether this association is modified by the presence of metabolic syndrome (MetS).
results_summary: An anti-inflammatory diet showed a borderline protective effect against 10-year CVD incidence, particularly among participants without MetS at baseline. No protective effect was observed among participants with MetS.
population_specificity: 3042 healthy adults (1514 men and 1528 women) living in the greater area of Athens.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the impact of an anti-inflammatory diet on health by focusing on food choices that modulate inflammatory pathways.
results_summary: The study suggests that an anti-inflammatory diet, emphasizing whole, plant-based foods rich in healthy fats and phytonutrients while maintaining stable glycemic responses, can positively influence inflammatory pathways. No specific quantitative outcomes or adverse effects were reported.
population_specificity: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of the Anti-Inflammatory Diet (IBD-AID) as an adjunct dietary therapy for inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) by assessing symptom reduction and medication discontinuation.
results_summary: The study found that 60% of patients had a good or very good response to the diet, with all 11 reviewed patients discontinuing at least one IBD medication and experiencing symptom reduction, including decreased bowel frequency. The mean Harvey Bradshaw Index (HBI) and Modified Truelove and Witts Severity Index (MTLWSI) scores significantly improved after the diet.
population_specificity: 40 patients with IBD (11 underwent detailed review: 8 with Crohn’s disease and 3 with ulcerative colitis, aged 19-70 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of an anti-inflammatory diet as part of an integrated therapeutic strategy for managing PCOS and obesity, focusing on improving insulin resistance, weight loss, and ovulation rates.
results_summary: The study found that an anti-inflammatory diet, combined with nutritional education, exercise, and lifestyle changes, can improve insulin resistance, sustained weight loss, and ovulation rates in PCOS patients. It highlighted the interaction between oxidative stress, low-grade inflammation, and PCOS.
population_specificity: Women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) and obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the role of antioxidants in mitigating oxidative damage and their therapeutic potential in managing age-related macular degeneration (AMD).
results_summary: The study found that specific antioxidants, including vitamins C and E, lutein, zeaxanthin, and Coenzyme Q10, were effective in slowing AMD progression, though challenges like patient variability and long-term safety concerns persist. Emerging therapies and lifestyle interventions also showed promise in holistic AMD management.
population_specificity: Individuals with age-related macular degeneration (AMD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of antioxidant agents in mitigating oxidative stress in murine models of fluorosis-induced toxicity.
results_summary: Antioxidants like vitamin C, vitamin E, selenium, and polyphenolic compounds showed variations in reducing oxidative stress markers and improving antioxidant activity in fluorosis-induced rodents, with effectiveness noted in prophylactic and concurrent treatments. However, methodological differences prevented standardization.
population_specificity: Murine (rodent) models with fluorosis induction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how oxidative stress biomarkers indicate the damage degree of cerebral hemorrhage and explore antioxidant-based treatments as a potential intervention.
results_summary: The study found that patients with cerebral hemorrhage exhibited increased levels of oxidative stress markers, suggesting that these markers could be used for evaluation, diagnosis, and prognosis, with antioxidant-based treatment proposed as a new alternative.
population_specificity: Patients with intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-inflammatory potential of dietary anthocyanin (ACN) in type 2 diabetic (T2D), T2D-at-risk, and healthy individuals, and assess the association of diet with inflammatory biomarkers.
results_summary: The study found a significant reduction in pro-inflammatory biomarkers (interleukin-6, interleukin-18, and tumour necrosis factor-α) in the T2D group, and improvements in some biochemical parameters (fasting blood glucose, LDL cholesterol, uric acid) in the T2D-at-risk group. The dietary inflammatory index (DII) scores indicated that T2D participants followed an anti-inflammatory diet, which may have enhanced the effects of ACN supplementation.
population_specificity: Type 2 diabetic (T2D), T2D-at-risk, and healthy individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore advancements, limitations, and future perspectives of electrochemical detection methods for lipophilic antioxidants (LAOs).
results_summary: The review highlights electrochemical methods for LAO detection, including cyclic voltammetry and differential pulse voltammetry, and discusses their application in analyzing synthetic and natural antioxidants. It also covers medium selection and sample preparation strategies.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on analytical methods, not human subjects)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of TBABr and BTA as stabilization agents for paper documents containing verdigris pigment under mild accelerated degradation conditions.
results_summary: TBABr provided superior stabilization compared to BTA, as evidenced by molecular weight measurements, though both treatments showed some limitations in preventing degradation spots. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy revealed differences in copper oxidation states between treatments, suggesting varying degradation mechanisms.
population_specificity: Historically accurate mock-up paper samples containing verdigris pigment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of resistance training on endogenous antioxidants in healthy older individuals.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found no significant effects of resistance training on catalase levels or overall antioxidant activity, but it showed a reduction in superoxide dismutase and an increase in glutathione peroxidase.
population_specificity: Healthy older individuals

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate the therapeutic potential of water-soluble, low-toxicity silver nanoclusters (Ag9 NCs) as self-cascade antioxidants for enhanced reactive oxygen species clearance, particularly in inflammatory conditions.
results_summary: Ag9 NCs demonstrated superior superoxide dismutase-like (86.7% inhibition) and catalase-like (Km = 20.37 mM, Vmax = 3.13 × 10-3 mM s-1) activities compared to Ag nanoparticles, with enhanced targeting to inflammatory cells due to their negative surface charge. The nanoclusters also showed significant therapeutic effects in cell cultures and an inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) model.
population_specificity: Inflammatory cells and an inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how structured exercise therapy (SET) improves muscle strength and regeneration by increasing endogenous antioxidants and mitochondrial respiration in a large animal model of ischemic myopathy.
results_summary: SET increased walking distance, muscle strength, and mitochondrial respiration while reducing oxidative stress and markers of cell death in ischemic muscles. The study suggests SET enhances muscle health by boosting antioxidant activity and functional regeneration despite ongoing ischemia.
population_specificity: Large animal model (unilateral hind limb ischemia) simulating human peripheral artery disease (PAD).
effective_dosage: Not specified (exercise intervention: thrice weekly for 4 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the relationship between oxidative stress and ovarian cancer, as well as the potential role of antioxidants in preventing and treating ovarian cancer.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that oxidative stress contributes to ovarian cancer progression and drug resistance, and antioxidants may offer therapeutic potential, though specific efficacy data are not detailed.
population_specificity: Ovarian cancer patients (theoretical or reviewed studies, not a specific clinical trial population).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of melatonin foliar application on saffron leaf composition, fatty acid production, and antioxidant enzyme activity during late growth stages.
results_summary: The study found that 100 μM melatonin significantly increased fatty acid production (C8:0, C10:0, C12:0, C18:0) and boosted antioxidant enzyme activity (ascorbate peroxidase, catalase), with the highest effects observed when applied 124 days after germination.
population_specificity: Saffron plants during late growth stages.
effective_dosage: 0, 50, 100, 150, and 200 μM melatonin applied as foliar sprays.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the use of nanocarrier systems for enhancing the delivery of topical antioxidants to the skin and their role in managing oxidative stress-related disorders.
results_summary: The study highlights that nanotechnology-based delivery systems (e.g., nanoemulsions, liposomes, SLNs, NLCs, polymeric nanoparticles) can improve antioxidant penetration through the skin, potentially aiding in oxidative stress management. It also discusses ROS formation, antioxidant therapy's role, and natural antioxidant sources, emphasizing the clinical potential of topical antioxidant therapy.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on skin-related oxidative stress disorders).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of antioxidant treatments in preserving retinal function in rodents with diabetic retinopathy using electroretinography (ERG).
results_summary: Antioxidants generally protected rodent retinas from functional losses, preserving the amplitudes of a- and b-waves and oscillatory potentials, but prolonged exposure showed they could only delay, not stop, adverse changes.
population_specificity: Rodents (animal model for diabetic retinopathy)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the latest advancements in nano-antioxidants for treating skin-related diseases, focusing on their permeability, sustained-release ability, and multifunctionality.
results_summary: The study found that nano-antioxidants show promise in treating skin-related diseases due to their enhanced permeability and sustained-release properties, potentially overcoming limitations of traditional therapies. They categorized skin diseases into four groups and highlighted future directions for nano-antioxidant applications.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of research on skin-related diseases).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of mitochondrial-targeted antioxidants (MitoQ10) versus heat therapy in ameliorating PCOS-like features induced by a high-fat sugar diet in rats.
results_summary: Both MitoQ10 and heat therapy improved PCOS-like features, with MitoQ10 showing superior effects over heat therapy in reducing hormonal imbalances, oxidative stress markers, and improving ovarian morphology.
population_specificity: Female rats with diet-induced PCOS-like features.
effective_dosage: 500 µmol/L MitoQ10 in clean drinking water daily.
study_duration: 8 weeks (from week 14 to week 22 of the study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the current knowledge on the role of dysbiosis and oxidative stress in asthma pathogenesis and explore the potential of probiotics, prebiotics, and antioxidants in treatment and prevention.
results_summary: The study highlights that probiotics, prebiotics, and antioxidants may support asthma treatment by modulating the immune system, reducing oxidative stress, and exhibiting anti-inflammatory properties. However, specific efficacy data on antioxidants alone are not detailed.
population_specificity: General discussion on asthma patients, no specific population mentioned.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate a novel polyphenol delivery system (liposome-cyclodextrin) for its antioxidant and ECM protective effects in skin fibroblasts.
results_summary: The combinatorial delivery system promoted collagen and elastin synthesis, inhibited collagenase activity, and demonstrated multitargeted efficacy in both normal and stressed conditions.
population_specificity: Skin fibroblasts (NHDFs) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of oxidative stress and antioxidants in bone tissue metabolism among elderly individuals with osteoporotic hip fractures.
results_summary: The study found that oxidative balance was disrupted in patients with hip fractures, with significantly lower total antioxidant status (TAS) and oxidative stress index (OSI) levels, and higher total oxidant status (TOS) and paraoxonase-1 (PON-1) levels compared to healthy controls.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals (over 65 years) with osteoporotic hip fractures (intertrochanteric or femoral neck fractures).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the molecular mechanisms of oxidative stress in cisplatin-induced hearing loss (CIHL) and evaluate preclinical and clinical studies testing antioxidants for CIHL to guide future trials.
results_summary: The abstract highlights the role of cochlear oxidative stress in CIHL and reviews existing studies on antioxidants, suggesting potential for future clinical trials but does not present specific efficacy results.
population_specificity: Pediatric and adult patients receiving cisplatin treatment (specific population not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the use of flavonoid nanoparticle delivery systems to enhance bioavailability and explore their biomedical applications.
results_summary: The study found that nanoparticle-flavonoid formulations improve bioavailability and bioactivity, with potential applications in antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and anticancer therapies. Safety and toxicity considerations were also discussed.
population_specificity: Not specified (review article)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of antioxidants in disease prevention and therapy, focusing on the complexity of redox dynamics and the need for targeted antioxidant approaches.
results_summary: The study found that while antioxidants show some beneficial effects in clinical trials, they generally fail as therapeutic agents due to oversimplification of redox dynamics and non-specific ROS scavenging, which disrupts cellular signaling. The authors propose that identifying specific types of oxidative stress in diseases could lead to more effective, targeted antioxidant therapies.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of oxidative stress in disease conditions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of combining antiangiogenic and antioxidant therapies to enhance treatment effectiveness for retinal diseases, particularly Age-related Macular Degeneration.
results_summary: The study highlights the potential of co-delivery systems with antioxidants and antiangiogenic agents but notes a lack of extensive clinical data on long-term outcomes and optimal combinations, leaving full efficacy and risk profiles unclear.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals (over 50 years old) with Age-related Macular Degeneration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the synthesis and medicinal applications of synthetic organoselenium compounds, including their antioxidant properties and broader biological activities.
results_summary: The study highlights the shift in focus from antioxidant properties to broader biological applications, such as anticancer, antimicrobial, antiviral, antidiabetic, antithyroid, and anti-inflammatory therapies, demonstrating their potential in disease treatment.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of synthetic compounds)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of plant-based antioxidants as adjuvant therapy in modulating inflammatory markers and improving clinical outcomes in adults with asthma.
results_summary: The review found that plant-based antioxidants effectively modulated inflammatory cytokines, improved oxidative status, lung function, and airway inflammatory markers, and enhanced overall quality of life with fewer asthma exacerbations.
population_specificity: Adults with asthma

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of oxidative stress in neuropsychiatric disorders and evaluate the potential of antioxidant therapy as an adjuvant treatment.
results_summary: The study found that antioxidants like N-acetylcysteine, sulforaphane, and others showed potential in alleviating neuropsychiatric symptoms by mitigating excitotoxicity, enhancing synaptic plasticity, and reducing microglial overactivation. Preclinical and clinical evidence supports their use, though further research is needed to confirm efficacy and mechanisms.
population_specificity: Patients with neuropsychiatric disorders (e.g., schizophrenia, major depressive disorder, anxiety disorders) and neurodegenerative diseases (e.g., Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, Huntington's).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of dental treatments and fluoride varnish applications on salivary oxidative stress biomarkers and antioxidants in children with severe early childhood caries (S-ECC) compared to caries-free children.
results_summary: The study found that dental treatments and fluoride varnish applications led to decreased oxidative stress markers (AOPP, DT, KYN, AGE, LHP, MDA) and increased antioxidant levels (TSH, Cu/Zn-SOD) in children with S-ECC. Antioxidant parameters post-treatment were significantly higher in the study group than in the control group.
population_specificity: Children aged 3-5 years with severe early childhood caries (S-ECC) and caries-free children.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antifungal effects of antioxidants on *Thecaphora frezzii* hyphae and identify potential targets for these compounds.
results_summary: Lipoic acid demonstrated inhibitory effects on *T. frezzii*, causing loss of cytosolic proteins, hydrolysis of triglycerides, and alterations in fungal cell structure, ultimately leading to cell death. Butylated hydroxyanisole and methylparaben also showed antifungal activity, but lipoic acid was selected for further study due to its environmental safety.
population_specificity: *Thecaphora frezzii* (peanut smut pathogen) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the relationship between serum antioxidant levels (ALB, UA, SOD) and cognitive dysfunction in patients with major depressive disorder (MDD).
results_summary: The study found that serum antioxidants (ALB and UA) correlated with cognitive function in MDD patients, with UA acting as a protective factor against cognitive impairment. MDD patients had significantly lower ALB levels and worse cognitive performance compared to healthy controls.
population_specificity: 105 first-episode drug-naïve MDD patients and 53 healthy controls.
study_duration: Data collected from February 2022 to October 2023 (duration not explicitly stated)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if microbe-derived antioxidants (MA) could mitigate the negative effects of glyphosate on the digestive function and gut microbiota of Eriocheir sinensis.
results_summary: The study found that glyphosate negatively impacted digestive tissue function and gut microbiota in E. sinensis, but MA ameliorated these effects, improving trypsin activity and reducing harmful microbial populations.
population_specificity: Eriocheir sinensis (Chinese mitten crabs)
effective_dosage: Not specified for MA (glyphosate dose: 48.945 mg/L)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of natural functional antioxidants in managing diabetes mellitus (DM) and its oxidative stress complications.
results_summary: The study found that vitamins and phytochemicals from natural sources have high antioxidant impacts, reducing oxidative stress and cell damage, and may help regulate reactive oxygen species (ROS), control epigenetic mutations, and manage hyperglycemia. These compounds show potential as bioactive antidiabetic agents.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on diabetes mellitus and oxidative stress).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the clinical effects of using antioxidant-supplemented culture media throughout the IVF process, particularly on embryo development and single vitrified blastocyst transfer outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that antioxidant-supplemented media significantly improved fertilization rates and blastocyst rates, with notable benefits for patients aged 35-40 years, including better embryo development, blastocyst quality, and live birth rates, while younger patients showed minimal effects.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing IVF, stratified by maternal age (<35 years and 35-40 years).
study_duration: Throughout the IVF process (duration not explicitly stated)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the role of antioxidants in Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) and their impact on drug-induced liver injury (DILI).
results_summary: The study found that plant-based antioxidants in TCM can neutralize reactive oxygen species (ROS) and show favorable therapeutic outcomes for DILI, with emphasis on their synergistic effects and repair mechanisms.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on DILI patients).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the compounds in Psychotria malayana leaf extract responsible for α-glucosidase inhibitory (AGI) and antioxidant activities and analyze their binding interactions with the enzyme.
results_summary: The study identified several compounds (1-cyclohexene-1-carboxylic, propanoic, butanedioic, and D-gluconic acid) with AGI activity and others with antioxidant activity, reporting these findings for the first time. Molecular docking revealed most compounds bind to the enzyme's catalytic site, suggesting potential for diabetes therapy.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or in-silico study)
